content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

A constant volume of pizza dough is formed into a cylinder with a relatively small height and large radius. The dough is spun and tossed into the air in such a way that the height of the dough decreases as the radius increases, but it retains its cylindrical shape. At time <math alttext="t equals k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the height of the dough is <math alttext="one third "><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> inch, the radius of the dough is <math alttext="12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches, and the radius of the dough is increasing at a rate of <math alttext="2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches per minute.

(a)   At time <math alttext="t equals k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, at what rate is the area of the circular surface of the dough increasing with respect to time? Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

A constant volume of pizza dough is formed into a cylinder with a relatively small height and large radius. The dough is spun and tossed into the air in such a way that the height of the dough decreases as the radius increases, but it retains its cylindrical shape. At time <math alttext="t equals k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the height of the dough is <math alttext="one third "><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> inch, the radius of the dough is <math alttext="12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches, and the radius of the dough is increasing at a rate of <math alttext="2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches per minute.

(a)   At time <math alttext="t equals k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, at what rate is the area of the circular surface of the dough increasing with respect to time? Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

(b)   At time <math alttext="t equals k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, at what rate is the height of the dough decreasing with respect to time? Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure. (The volume <math alttext="V"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a cylinder with radius <math alttext="r"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and height <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="V equals, pi r squared, times h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.)

(c)   Write an expression for the rate of change of the height of the dough with respect to the radius of the dough in terms of height <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="r"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.3: Rates of Change in Applied Contexts Other Than Motion

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
